campaign.title: Data Privacy for Small Business
campaign.subject: Your customers care about privacy. Here's what you need to know.
campaign.description: Understanding data privacy obligations and best practices for SMBs

slides.title: Privacy Matters

stats.concern: 79% of consumers are concerned about how businesses use their data
stats.trust: 81% say they'd stop doing business with a company after a data breach
stats.preference: 73% prefer businesses with clear privacy practices

slides.narration: Privacy isn't just for big tech companies. Your customers care—a lot. Seventy-nine percent are concerned about how businesses use their data. Eighty-one percent would stop doing business with you after a data breach. Seventy-three percent prefer businesses with clear privacy practices. Privacy is a competitive advantage now.

slides.title: What Data You Collect

content.headline: You Probably Collect More Than You Think

data_types.examples: What they bought, when, how much
What they like, how they interact
IP addresses, device info from website

slides.narration: You probably collect more data than you realize. Contact info: names, emails, phones, addresses. Transaction data: what they bought, when, how much. Communication history: every email, call, and message. Preferences: what they like, how they interact with you. Technical data: IP addresses and device info from your website. All of this is data you're responsible for protecting.

slides.title: Your Obligations

content.headline: What the Law Requires

requirements.how: Notify affected customers if breach occurs

content.note: Requirements vary by state/country—some are stricter than others

slides.narration: What does the law require? You must tell people what you collect—that means a privacy policy on your website. Protect data from breaches—secure storage, access controls. Allow deletion requests—process them within required timeframes. Get consent for marketing—real opt-in for emails and texts. Report breaches if they happen—notify affected customers. Requirements vary by location, but these basics apply almost everywhere.

slides.title: Best Practices

content.headline: Privacy Best Practices for Small Business

practices.why: Only people who need it should have it
Delete old data you don't need
Tell customers what you do with their info

slides.narration: Best practices for small business. Collect only what you need—less data means less risk. Use secure tools—encrypted, reputable platforms. Limit access—only people who need data should have it. Keep it updated—delete old data you don't need anymore. Be transparent—tell customers what you do with their information. These practices protect you and build trust.

slides.title: Privacy as Trust

content.headline: Privacy Is Actually a Marketing Advantage

advantages.how: "We respect your privacy" is a selling point
People share more when they trust you

slides.narration: Here's the flip side: privacy is actually a marketing advantage. Differentiation—'We respect your privacy' is a real selling point now. Customer trust—people share more when they trust you. Better data quality—consent-based data is more accurate and useful. Reduced risk—fewer breaches, fewer legal headaches. Future-proof—regulations are only getting stricter, so get ahead now.

slides.title: Your Privacy Checklist

content.headline: Quick Privacy Wins for Your Business

checklist.item: Add a privacy policy to your website

slides.narration: Quick privacy wins you can do today. Add a privacy policy to your website—thirty minutes. Review what data you actually collect—fifteen minutes. Check your email opt-in process is compliant—ten minutes. Secure your customer database with proper access controls—time varies. Create a simple process for deletion requests—thirty minutes. Small investments, big protection.

slides.title: Get Privacy-Ready

content.headline: Ready to Build Customer Trust Through Privacy?

slides.narration: Ready to build customer trust through privacy? Download the complete privacy checklist—everything you need to get compliant and build trust. Or review our privacy practices to see how we handle your data. Privacy isn't a burden—it's an opportunity to stand out.
